informal_statement:
Example 2 Prove that if two given positive numbers $p \leqslant q$, then for any $\alpha, \beta, \gamma, \delta, \varepsilon \in[p, q]$, we have
$$(\alpha+\beta+\gamma+\delta+\varepsilon)\left(\frac{1}{\alpha}+\frac{1}{\beta}+\frac{1}{\gamma}+\frac{1}{\delta}+\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right) \leqslant 25+6\left(\sqrt{\frac{p}{q}}-\sqrt{\frac{q}{p}}\right)^{2}$$

and determine the necessary and sufficient conditions for equality. (1977 USA Mathematical Olympiad)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- Example 2 Prove that if two given positive numbers $p \leqslant q$, then for any $\alpha, \beta, \gamma, \delta, \varepsilon \in[p, q]$, we have
$$(\alpha+\beta+\gamma+\delta+\varepsilon)\left(\frac{1}{\alpha}+\frac{1}{\beta}+\frac{1}{\gamma}+\frac{1}{\delta}+\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right) \leqslant 25+6\left(\sqrt{\frac{p}{q}}-\sqrt{\frac{q}{p}}\right)^{2}$$

and determine the necessary and sufficient conditions for equality. (1977 USA Mathematical Olympiad) -/
theorem inequalities_601852 {p q : ℝ} (hp : 0 < p) (hq : 0 < q)
  (h : p ≤ q) :
  ∀ α β γ δ ε : ℝ, α ∈ Icc p q → β ∈ Icc p q → γ ∈ Icc p q →
  δ ∈ Icc p q → ε ∈ Icc p q →
  (α + β + γ + δ + ε) * (1/α + 1/β + 1/γ + 1/δ + 1/ε) ≤
  25 + 6 * (sqrt (p/q) - sqrt (q/p))^2 ∧
  ((α + β + γ + δ + ε) * (1/α + 1/β + 1/γ + 1/δ + 1/ε) =
   25 + 6 * (sqrt (p/q) - sqrt (q/p))^2 ↔
   (α = β ∧ β = γ ∧ γ = δ ∧ δ = ε)) :=

soln_description:
Proof: By the symmetry of equation (5), without loss of generality, let $a+b+c=1$, where $0<a, b, c<1$. Thus,
$$\sum_{\text {cyc }} \frac{a}{b+c}=\sum_{\text {cyc }} f(a) \geqslant \frac{3}{2}$$

where $f(x)=\frac{x}{1-x}$. By the convexity of $f(x)$ on $x \in(0,1)$, we have
$$\frac{1}{3} \sum_{\text {cyc }} f(a) \geqslant f\left(\frac{a+b+c}{3}\right)=f\left(\frac{1}{3}\right)=\frac{1}{2}$$

which means equation (6) holds.
For real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}, b_{1}, b_{2}, \cdots, b_{n}$, we have
$$\begin{aligned}
& \left(a_{1}^{2}+a_{2}^{2}+\cdots+a_{n}^{2}\right)\left(b_{1}^{2}+b_{2}^{2}+\cdots+b_{n}^{2}\right) \\
\geqslant & \left(a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}$$

This is the famous Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, whose proof has been mentioned before and will not be repeated here. The focus of our current discussion is the various applications of the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality.

For equation (7), we have several commonly used forms.
For positive real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}, b_{1}, b_{2}, \cdots, b_{n}$, we have
$$\begin{array}{c}
\sqrt{\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}\right)} \\
\geqslant \sqrt{a_{1} b_{1}}+\sqrt{a_{2} b_{2}}+\cdots+\sqrt{a_{n} b_{n}}, \\
\frac{a_{1}^{2}}{b_{1}}+\frac{a_{2}^{2}}{b_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}^{2}}{b_{n}} \geqslant \frac{\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)^{2}}{b_{1}+b_{2}+\cdots+b_{n}} \\
\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}^{2}}+\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}^{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}^{2}} \geqslant \frac{1}{a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}}\left(\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}+\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}}\right)^{2} \\
\frac{a_{1}}{b_{1}}+\frac{a_{2}}{b_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{a_{n}}{b_{n}} \geqslant \frac{\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)^{2}}{a_{1} b_{1}+a_{2} b_{2}+\cdots+a_{n} b_{n}} .
\end{array}$$
informal_statement:
Example 3 Proof: For positive real numbers $a, b, c$, we have
$$\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b} \geqslant \frac{3}{2} .$$
informal_proof:
Given positive real numbers $a$, $b$, and $c$. We first establish the positivity of the denominators. Since $a > 0$ and $b > 0$, their sum $a+b > 0$. Similarly, $b+c > 0$ and $c+a > 0$.

We want to prove the inequality:
$$ \frac{a}{b+c} + \frac{b}{c+a} + \frac{c}{a+b} \ge \frac{3}{2} $$
To prove this, we rearrange the inequality to show that the difference between the left-hand side and the right-hand side is non-negative:
$$ \frac{a}{b+c} + \frac{b}{c+a} + \frac{c}{a+b} - \frac{3}{2} \ge 0 $$
We combine the terms on the left-hand side into a single fraction with a common denominator, which is $(b+c)(c+a)(a+b)$. After performing the algebraic expansion and simplification, we get:
$$ \frac{a(c+a)(a+b) + b(b+c)(a+b) + c(b+c)(c+a) - \frac{3}{2}(b+c)(c+a)(a+b)}{(b+c)(c+a)(a+b)} $$
For this fraction to be non-negative, we need to show that both the numerator and the denominator are non-negative, and the denominator is strictly positive.

We have already established that the denominator $(b+c)(c+a)(a+b)$ is strictly positive since it is the product of three positive terms.

Now, we focus on proving that the numerator is non-negative:
$$ a(c+a)(a+b) + b(b+c)(a+b) + c(b+c)(c+a) - \frac{3}{2}(b+c)(c+a)(a+b) \ge 0 $$
This inequality can be established by leveraging several fundamental inequalities, including the fact that the square of any real number is non-negative. Specifically, we utilize the non-negativity of $(a-b)^2$, $(b-c)^2$, and $(c-a)^2$. We also use the positivity of products of the given positive numbers $a, b, c$.

After applying these principles, we find that the numerator is indeed greater than or equal to zero.

Since the numerator is non-negative and the denominator is positive, the entire fraction is non-negative. This implies that:
$$ \frac{a}{b+c} + \frac{b}{c+a} + \frac{c}{a+b} - \frac{3}{2} \ge 0 $$
Rearranging this inequality gives us the desired result:
$$ \frac{a}{b+c} + \frac{b}{c+a} + \frac{c}{a+b} \ge \frac{3}{2} $$
This concludes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 3 Proof: For positive real numbers $a, b, c$, we have
$$\frac{a}{b+c}+\frac{b}{c+a}+\frac{c}{a+b} \geqslant \frac{3}{2} .$$ -/
theorem inequalities_597635 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    3 / 2 ≤ a / (b + c) + b / (c + a) + c / (a + b) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

theorem inequalities_597635 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    3 / 2 ≤ a / (b + c) + b / (c + a) + c / (a + b) := by 
  have h1 : 0 < b + c := by linarith
  have h2 : 0 < c + a := by linarith
  have h3 : 0 < a + b := by linarith
  
  have h4 : a / (b + c) + b / (c + a) + c / (a + b) - 3 / 2 ≥ 0 := by
    have h5 : (a / (b + c) + b / (c + a) + c / (a + b) - 3 / 2) = 
        (a * (c + a) * (a + b) + b * (b + c) * (a + b) + c * (b + c) * (c + a) - 3 / 2 * (b + c) * (c + a) * (a + b)) / ((b + c) * (c + a) * (a + b)) := by
      field_simp
      ring
    rw [h5]
    apply div_nonneg
    -- To show that the numerator is non-negative, we need to prove
    -- a * (c + a) * (a + b) + b * (b + c) * (a + b) + c * (b + c) * (c + a) - 3 / 2 * (b + c) * (c + a) * (a + b) ≥ 0
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (b - c), sq_nonneg (c - a),
      sq_nonneg (a^2 - b^2), sq_nonneg (b^2 - c^2), sq_nonneg (c^2 - a^2),
      mul_pos ha hb, mul_pos hb hc, mul_pos ha hc, 
      sq_nonneg (a * b - b * c), sq_nonneg (b * c - c * a), sq_nonneg (c * a - a * b)]
    -- denominators positive
    positivity
  
  linarith

soln_description:
(1) Let $g(x)=(x-2) f(x)+m x^{2}+2$, then $g(x)=(x-2) e^{x}+2 m x+2$. For $x>0$, the inequality $(x-2) f(x)+m x^{2}+2>0$ always holds $\Leftrightarrow$ for $x>0$, $g(x)>0$ always holds.

Since
$$
g^{\prime}(x)=e^{x}+(x-2) e^{x}+2 m=(x-1) e^{x}+2 m, g^{\prime \prime}(x)=e^{x}+(x-1) e^{x}=x e^{x}
$$

Therefore, for $x>0$, $g^{\prime \prime}(x)=x e^{x}>0$, and $g^{\prime}(x)=(x-1) e^{x}+2 m$ is an increasing function on the interval $[0,+\infty)$.
Also, from $g(2)=4 m+2$, we know $m>-\frac{1}{2}$.
(1) If $-\frac{1}{2}<m<\frac{1}{2}$, then
$$
g^{\prime}(0)=-1+2 m<0, \lim _{x \rightarrow+\infty} g^{\prime}(x)=+\infty
$$

At this time, $g^{\prime}(x)$ has a unique zero point in the interval $(0,2)$, denoted as $x_{0}$, then $0<x_{0}<2$, and $g^{\prime}(x)<0$ for $x \in(0, x_{0})$, $g^{\prime}(x)>0$ for $x \in\left(x_{0},+\infty\right)$, so $g(x)$ is decreasing on $(0, x_{0})$ and increasing on $\left(x_{0},+\infty\right)$, and $g(0)=0$, so there exists $x \in(0, x_{0})$ such that $g(x)<0$, which contradicts the condition that $g(x)>0$ for $x>0$.
(2) If $m \geq \frac{1}{2}$, then for $x>0$,
$$
g^{\prime}(x)>g^{\prime}(0)=-1+2 m \geq 0
$$

At this time, $g(x)$ is an increasing function on $[0,+\infty)$, so for $x>0$, $g(x)>g(0)=0$, therefore, $m \geq \frac{1}{2}$ meets the requirement.
From (1) and (2), the range of $m$ is $\left[\frac{1}{2},+\infty\right)$;
(2) Since $x_{1}, x_{2}$ are the two zeros of the function $f(x)=e^{x}-m x$, we have
$$
e^{x_{1}}=m x_{1}, e^{x_{2}}=m x_{2}, m\left(x_{1}+x_{2}\right)=e^{x_{1}}+e^{x_{2}}, m\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)=e^{x_{1}}-e^{x_{2}}
$$

Assume $x_{1}>x_{2}$, it is easy to know $m \neq 0$, combining the above two equations and eliminating $m$, we get
$$
x_{1}+x_{2}=\frac{\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)\left(e^{x_{1}}+e^{x_{2}}\right)}{e^{x_{1}}-e^{x_{2}}}=\frac{\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)\left(e^{x_{1}-x_{2}}+1\right)}{e^{x_{1}-x_{2}}-1}
$$

Also, from (1), we know that for $m=\frac{1}{2}$, when $x>0$, $g(x)=(x-2) e^{x}+2 m x+2>0$ always holds.
So when $x>0$, $(x-2) e^{x}+x+2>0$ always holds; so when $x>0$,
$$
\frac{x\left(e^{x}+1\right)}{e^{x}-1}-2=\frac{x e^{x}+x-2 e^{x}+2}{e^{x}-1}=\frac{(x-2) e^{x}+x+2}{e^{x}-1}>0
$$

So
$$
x_{1}+x_{2}-2=\frac{\left(x_{1}-x_{2}\right)\left(e^{x_{1}-x_{2}}+1\right)}{e^{x_{1}-x_{2}}-1}-2>0, x_{1}+x_{2}>2
$$

When $x_{1}>2$, so $x_{1}+x_{2}>2$.
(20 points)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real Set
open scoped BigOperators

/- 14. Given $f(x)=e^{x}-m x$.
(1) If $x>0$, the inequality $(x-2) f(x)+m x^{2}+2>0$ always holds, find the range of real number $m$;
(2) If $x_{1}, x_{2}$ are two zeros of the function $f(x)$, prove that $x_{1}+x_{2}=2$. -/
theorem algebra_162960 {f : ℝ → ℝ} (hf : ∀ x, f x = exp x - m * x)
  (m : ℝ) :
  (∀ x > 0, (x - 2) * f x + m * x^2 + 2 > 0) ↔ m ≥ 1 / 2 :=

soln_description:
Lemma 1 Let $0 \leqslant x \leqslant K \leqslant y$. Then $x y \leqslant K(x+y-K)$.
Proof of Lemma 1 Clearly,
$$
(K-x)(y-K) \geqslant 0 \text {. }
$$

Lemma 2 Let $0 \leqslant x \leqslant K \leqslant y \leqslant L \leqslant z$. Then $x y z \leqslant K L(x+y+z-K-L)$.
Proof of Lemma 2 In fact,
$$
\begin{array}{l}
x y z \leqslant K(x+y-K) z \\
\leqslant K L((x+y-K)+z-L) \\
=K L(x+y+z-K-L) .
\end{array}
$$

Lemmas 1 and 2 are proved.
$$
\text { Let } S=\sum_{i=1}^{3 n} a_{i}, K=a_{n}, L=a_{2 n} \text {. }
$$

Then by Lemma 1 we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} a_{n+i} a_{2 n+i} \\
\leqslant \sum_{i=1}^{n} K L\left(a_{i}+a_{n+i}+a_{2 n+i}-K-L\right) \\
=K L(S-n K-n L) .
\end{array}
$$

Using the AM-GM inequality, we get
$$
\begin{array}{l}
n K \cdot n L(S-n K-n L) \\
\leqslant\left(\frac{n L+n K+(S-n K-n L)}{3}\right)^{3}=\frac{S^{3}}{27} .
\end{array}
$$

When $a_{i}=1$, the equality holds in all the above inequalities. Therefore, the best value of $k_{n}$ is $27 n^{2}$.
informal_statement:
One, (40 points) Given a positive integer $n$, there are $3n$ numbers satisfying:
$$
0 \leqslant a_{1} \leqslant a_{2} \leqslant \cdots \leqslant a_{3 n},
$$

and $\left(\sum_{i=1}^{3 n} a_{i}\right)^{3} \geqslant k_{n}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} a_{n+i} a_{2 n+i}\right)$ always holds.
Find the best possible value of $k_{n}$ (expressed in terms of $n$).
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Finset Real

/- One, (40 points) Given a positive integer $n$, there are $3n$ numbers satisfying:
$$
0 \leqslant a_{1} \leqslant a_{2} \leqslant \cdots \leqslant a_{3 n},
$$

and $\left(\sum_{i=1}^{3 n} a_{i}\right)^{3} \geqslant k_{n}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} a_{n+i} a_{2 n+i}\right)$ always holds.
Find the best possible value of $k_{n}$ (expressed in terms of $n$). -/
theorem inequalities_323633 {n : ℕ} (hn : 0 < n) (a : ℕ → ℝ)
    (h₀ : ∀ i ∈ Icc 1 (3 * n), 0 ≤ a i) (h₁ : ∀ i ∈ Icc 1 (3 * n - 1), a i ≤ a (i + 1))
    (h₂ : (∑ i ∈ Icc 1 (3 * n), a i) ^ 3 ≥ k * (∑ i ∈ Icc 1 n, a i * a (n + i) * a (2 * n + i))) :
    k ≤ 27 * n ^ 2 := by

soln_description:
,- 1.4 .
$$
\begin{array}{l}
\text { Given } z^{3}=3|z|+2 \Rightarrow|z|^{3}=3|z|+2 \\
\Rightarrow(|z|-2)\left(|z|^{2}+2|z|+1\right)=0 \\
\Rightarrow|z|=2 \text {. }
\end{array}
$$

Then $z^{3}=8 \Rightarrow(z-2)\left(z^{2}+2 z+4\right)=0$.
Note that, $z$ is an imaginary number.
Thus $z^{2}+2 z+4=0 \Rightarrow\left|z^{2}+4\right|=|-2 z|=4$.
informal_statement: 1. Given the imaginary number $z$ satisfies the equation $z^{3}-3|z|-2=0$. Then $\left|z^{2}+4\right|=$ $\qquad$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 1. Given the imaginary number $z$ satisfies the equation $z^{3}-3|z|-2=0$. Then $\left|z^{2}+4\right|=$ $\qquad$ -/
